advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the time of this advert (September 1980), Heathkit introduced a music synthetiser board, a speech lab, a color graphic board, a color monitor and Microsoft BASIC and FORTRAN languages. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 ADVERT & PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Price list</b><br><br> <b>VP-111 </b>Low cost microcomputer <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-114 </b>Expansion kit for VP-111 (3 KB RAM, I/O port and connectors) <b>$76</b><br> <b>VP-711 </b>Original VIP microcomputer <b>$199</b><br> <b>VP-44 </b>On board RAM expansion (4 x 2114 RAM chips) <b>$36</b><br> <b>VP-590 </b>Color board <b>$69</b><br> <b>VP-595 </b>Simple sound board (256 programmable frequencies) with speaker <b>$30</b><br> <b>VP-550 </b>Super sound board (Synthetiser with two sound channels <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-551 </b>Super sound 4 channels expansion <b>$74</b><br> <b>VP-570 </b>4 KB RAM memory expansion board <b>$95</b><br> <b>VP-580 </b>Two players keypad <b>$20</b><br> <b>VP-585 </b>Keypad interface board <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-560 </b>Eprom board for two 2716 EPROMS <b>$34</b><br> <b>VP-565 </b>2716 EPROM programmer with software <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-575 </b>Expansion board with 5 expansions sockets <b>$59</b><br> <b>VP-700 </b>4 KB Tiny Basic <b>$39</b><br> <b>VP-701 </b>Floating point Basic (cassette) <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-710 </b>Game listings <b>$10</b><br> <b>VP-720 </b>Game listings II <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-601 </b>Keyboard 128-character ASCII <b>$69</b> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPAN ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It's an advert for both the YIS-503 and YIS-303 which were quite similar except for the keyboard and the memory size...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>...released in "l'Ordinateur Individuel" magazine n°12<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Fabien Neck and its <a href="http://www.system-cfg.com/" target="_blank">website</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMTEXT BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The brochure says:<br><font color="#666666"> When you buy, lease or rent word processing equipment from AM Jacquard Systems, you get our total commitment, now and in the future, that assures the successful installation and operation of your AMtext word processing system. <br><br> To support that commitment, we have offices in over 100 cities throughout North America staffed with skilled professionals ready to meet your neads with planning, training. supplies, and service... <br><br> ...The AMtext 100 is a true shared resource, multifunction information system capable of supporting multiple work stations and peripherals simultaneously. <br><br> The Amtext 425 and 425A are powerful stand-alone work stations with a full-page video display <br><br> The AMtext 225 is a low-cost system that turns electric typewriters into flexible text editors. <br><br> The AMtext product line includes a complete selection of peripheral devices, including telecommunications, an optical character reader. magnetic card reader, phototypesetters, daisy wheel printers. high-speed line and matrix printers, as well as mass storage on floppy and hard disk drive units. <br><br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.K. AD (OCT. 87) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The letters you send speak volumes for your company's image. Scrappy typing, untidy layouts and poor spelling announce that you're less than professional outfit.<br> Whereas beautifully presented correspondence shows quite clearly that you're a company to be reckoned with.<br> Now Amstrad's new wordprocessor with daisywhell printer and spellcheck facility means that any company can produce superb quality letters, reports and documents.<br> With the minimum of effort and for a minimal outlay.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
The FM-11 was announced as a higher-end model of the FM-8 in November 1982, simultaneously with the mass market FM-7 machine. The FM-11 series was intended to be used in offices. FM stands for "Fujitsu Micro". The FM-11AD was released as the same time as the FM-11EX and FM-11ST. The FM-11ST is a cut-down version of the FM-11AD: F-Basic built-in ROM and no floppy disk drives on standard model.
Japanese characters can be displayed within a 16 x 16 pixels matrix. Chinese characters (JIS level 1 kanji) ROM available as an option offers: JIS level 1 2965 characters, JIS non-kanji 453 characters.
The FM-11AD later evolved into FM-11AD2 and FM-11AD2+. Based on a Motorola 6809 processor it became quite popular in Japan as a Flex (operating system available for the 6809 based computers) system.
________________
Contributors: Jiro Kita
computer.graphics: 640 x 400 (2 screens), 640 x 200 (4 screens) with 8 colours
computer.keyboard: Complete professional keyboard with function keys and separated numeric keypad (JIS standard). 98 keys.
computer.name: FM 11 AD
computer.ports: Keyboard, Light pen, Tape interface, Monochrome video output, Color video output, Printer (parallel/Centronics), RS-232C, 5 expansion slots

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FM11-AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIN UNIT - FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> - Power out & power in<br> - Keyboard connector<br> - Light pen connector<br> - Tape interface<br> - Monochrome CRT video output<br> - Colour CRT video output<br> - Printer (parallel) connector<br> - 5 expansion slots.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> - Power out & power in<br> - Keyboard connector<br> - Light pen connector<br> - Tape interface<br> - Monochrome CRT video output<br> - Colour CRT video output<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CLOSE-UP (RIGHT)</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right: <br><br> - Printer connector<br> - 5 expansion slots<br> - optional Serial RS-232 slot <p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jiro Kita for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.size: 464 (W) x 360 (D) x 153 (H) mm / 11.8 Kg (13 Kg with addition floppy disk drive)
